title: Are We Part of the Drama of This World? | Sri Chanchalapathi Dasa | SB 2.5.26-29 | 19.07.2024
speaker: HG Chanchalapathi Dasa

segments.key_quote: And water being transformed from all life on Earth appears knew in order and as previously becomes qualitatively full of juice, touch, sound and form respectively.
segments.summary: The speaker reads verses from Srimad Bhagavatam describing the transformation of elements in the process of creation.

segments.key_quote: So in the same way Lord Brahma who is the director of this universe creator of the universe he is doing the set design
segments.summary: The speaker uses the analogy of a film director to explain how Lord Brahma creates the universe and assigns roles to living entities.

segments.key_quote: But a very fundamental deeper question is why have I become an actor in this drama but very rarely people think they are all busy with their roles they have to play mother father
segments.summary: The speaker raises the fundamental question of why we are part of this worldly drama and emphasizes that people are usually too engrossed in their roles to contemplate the deeper meaning.

segments.key_quote: We are the spirit soul we are playing the role of a man of a woman of an animal of a bird for some time and then the drama ends and then we will be an actor after he finishes one drama he'll get commissioned to do another drama so we will get another opportunity we will go to another situation
segments.summary: The speaker explains that we are all spirit souls playing different roles in this material world, designed by Lord Brahma, and questions why the soul has become entrapped.

segments.key_quote: And this Jeeva Shakti has developed a desire, I want to be independent of Krishna.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that we are all part of Krishna, but unlike sunlight which cannot be independent of the sun, we have developed the desire to be independent.

segments.key_quote: This desire of the living entity to be independent of Krishna is called unconstitutional desire.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the unconstitutional desire to be independent of Krishna, comparing it to a dream where sunlight can exist without the sun, and how Krishna creates the illusion of the material world to facilitate this desire.

segments.key_quote: But they follow religion, they follow Dharma. But they follow religion, they follow Dharma. With an aim that God will bless me so that all my various desires I have with my family, with my profession, with myself, I can fulfill all those desires with God's blessing.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses how many people recognize God but primarily seek His blessings to fulfill their own independent desires and ambitions.

segments.key_quote: Rarely we think, if I am part and parcel of Krishna, I have come from Krishna, what was Krishna's plan for me?
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts pursuing independent desires with aligning oneself with Krishna's plan, highlighting the initial stage of recognizing God as a fulfiller of personal dreams.

segments.key_quote: What does Krishna want me to do? If I am his.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the concept of Sharanagati (surrender) and aligning one's desires with Krishna's plan, referencing the Bhagavad Gita's teaching on surrendering to Krishna.

segments.key_quote: This is a drama. It's only a drama relationship. No substance.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that after surrender, one understands their true relationship with Krishna, contrasting it with the temporary and insubstantial relationships in the material world.

segments.key_quote: It all begins with ahamkara. Ahamkara means what? The living entity having a false identity.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the concept of Ahamkara (false ego/identity) as the root of our entanglement, contrasting it with the true identity of being part and parcel of Krishna.

segments.key_quote: And that experience and percept, understanding and experience of that relationship is called bhakti.
segments.summary: The speaker defines Bhakti as the understanding and experience of our true, intense, and loving relationship with Krishna.

segments.key_quote: The living entity has desire to be independent. Now Lord has to fulfill that. It is not possible to fulfill that. Because it is an unconstitutional desire.
segments.summary: The speaker explains how Brahma creates the material world to fulfill the living entity's desire to be independent, even though it's an unconstitutional desire.

segments.key_quote: We are related to Krishna, we are meant to have a serving relationship with Krishna but we have developed a desire, I want to be independent, I want to enjoy, I have my plans, I want to have nice relationship in the material world without Krishna.
segments.summary: The speaker uses the analogy of a child wanting the moon to illustrate how Krishna creates an illusory world to satisfy our unconstitutional desires for independence.

segments.key_quote: So that there is a sense of realism.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the importance of understanding the truth from the Shastras and Acharyas, and how Brahma creates a sense of realism in the material world.

segments.key_quote: Save and accept the Lord, no one can be called the enjoyer, but the living entity falsely desires to become the enjoyer. This is the origin of false ego.
segments.summary: The speaker reminds us that the material world is temporary and emphasizes that enlightenment comes from understanding the truth about the soul and its relationship with Krishna, highlighting false ego as the root of our problems.

segments.key_quote: I am the master, I am the enjoyer of everyone's activities and sacrifices.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the most confidential knowledge revealed by Krishna in the 9th chapter of the Bhagavad Gita, emphasizing that Krishna is the master and enjoyer of everything.

segments.key_quote: For love to happen, freedom is required.
segments.summary: The speaker answers a question about free will, explaining that it is necessary for love to exist and that our turning away from Krishna leads to independent desires and entrapment in Maya.

segments.key_quote: All living entities have have have free will. But that free will is most 100% manifest in human life.
segments.summary: The speaker continues discussing free will, explaining that it is most manifest in human life and that humans have the ability to understand the ultimate truth and escape the illusion of the material world.
